Toward More Intervention President Clinton opened the meeting of world leaders at the United Nations, urging the huge gathering to prepare the institution for a new age in which international forces would have to reach regularly and rapidly inside national boundaries to protect threatened people.

Clinton Prods the U.N. Toward More Intervention President Clinton opened the meeting of world leaders at the United Nations, urging the huge gathering to prepare the institution for a new age in which international forces would have to reach regularly and rapidly inside national boundaries to protect threatened people.

President Clinton met in back-to-back sessions with Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, but the White House said there was little progress on a final settlement.
U.N. Workers Slain in W. Timor A mob led by militiamen attacked a United Nations refugee office in West Timor, killing three staff members, including an American, and possibly another aid worker.

U.S. Gives Russians Sub Data President Clinton's national security adviser provided his Russian counterpart with a written summary of what American naval and intelligence officials believe caused the nuclear-powered sub Kursk to sink last month in the Barents Sea.

Turkey Blocks Gay Tourists The police barred several hundred gay Americans from visiting popular tourist sites near the port city Kusadasi and ordered them back aboard their cruise ship, prompting complaints by the State Department.

University Officials Resign Vice Chancellor Cheng Yiu-chung and his deputy, Wong Siu-lung, resigned from Hong Kong University after an inquiry found that they and an adviser to the territory's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, had pressed a prominent pollster not to publish surveys critical of Mr. Tung.
Suspects Arrested in Croatia Croatia said it had arrested two men suspected in a 1993 rampage that left more than 100 Bosnian Muslim villagers dead during the war of secession from Yugoslavia.
Abdul Haris Nasution A soldier and politician who fought for Indonesia's independence and may have missed a chance to lead his nation, he was 81.

Gore Says Prosperity Will Fuel Economic Goals President Al Gore offered his economic vision for the future, a book-length plan that hinged on optimistic fiscal forecasts and offered a mountain of detail. He said the 10 economic goals he outlined were attainable, given the nation's current prosperity, including cutting poverty below 10 percent, raising the level of home ownership and creating 10 million new high-technology jobs.

Several Teamsters officials said the executive board would vote today to endorse Mr. Gore, despite the union's often-expressed anger at his support for the China trade bill. The officials cited Mr. Gore's populist turn, his pledge to help working families and his promise to negotiate worker protections in trade agreements.

Gov. George W. Bush said Mr. Gore's campaign promises would consume the entire $4.6 trillion federal surplus projected for the next decade. Mr. Bush's accusations were a mirror image of the Gore campaign's own assertions that it is the Republican candidate who is threatening the surplus because of Mr. Bush's proposal to enact a $1.3 trillion tax cut over 10 years, and his spending programs.
Prominent Republicans say they worry that the Bush candidacy has floundered, allowing Vice President Gore to build on his velocity from the Democratic convention.
The stalemate continued over the Bush and Gore campaigns' differing proposals for debates.
The shows and networks chosen by Mr. Bush have never reached even half as many viewers as the least-watched previous debate.

Bid for Tobacco Settlement Lorillard Tobacco and the Liggett Group were said to have held preliminary talks with plaintiffs' lawyers in recent months in a bid to resolve all nationwide smokers' claims against the tobacco industry.

Signs of Ancient Cannibalism Scientists have found what they say is the first direct evidence of cannibalism among prehistoric Indians in the American Southwest, butchered human bones and stone cutting tools stained with human blood at the site of an ancient Anasazi settlement.

5 Youths Arrested in Killing Of Food Deliveryman Prosecutors in Queens accused five teenagers from middle-class families of beating a Chinese takeout deliveryman to death because they did not want to pay for their food.

Racketeering Charges Levied The Manhattan district attorney charged 38 union officials, contractors and reputed mobsters with bribery, bid-rigging or other racketeering schemes involving public and private building projects.

Ex-Doctor Admits Murders Michael J. Swango, a former doctor, admitted that he used lethal injections to murder four patients at a Long Island hospital. Prosecutors, citing a notebook they said he had kept, said he had killed for pleasure.

Police Shake-Up Begins Bernard B. Kerik, the new commissioner, announced 30 changes in senior posts, including replacement of the assistant chief in the Bronx, where murders have risen, and the chief of police patrols.

Warning Signs for Violence The F.B.I., responding to a spate of school shootings, gave educators a report listing warning signs that include an obsession with violence and access to guns at home. But officials asserted that they were not offering a profile of school shooters.

Ban on Gay Group Abandoned The Orange Unified Board of Education, a suburban Los Angeles district, agreed to let a group of gay students and their supporters hold meetings at a high school, settling a federal lawsuit that had challenged the district's ban of the group.

Sampras and Davenport Win Pete Sampras beat Richard Krajicek, 4-6, 7-6 (6), 6-4, 6-2, in a quarterfinals match. Lindsay Davenport beat the defending United States Open champion, Serena Williams, 6-4, 6-2.

Tire Failure Investigation Documents released on Capitol Hill provided additional evidence that Bridgestone/Firestone and possibly Ford knew about a pattern of tire failures long before a recall was announced in August, and lawmakers began calling for tighter regulation of the auto and tire industries.
Expanding in Consumer Finance Citigroup said it would buy Associates First Capital, the biggest American consumer finance company, for about $31.1 billion in stock.

Setback for Music Start-Up A federal judge ruled that the online music distribution company MP3.com had infringed the copyrights of Universal Music Group, and he ordered it to pay damages that could amount to $250 million.
Low Ebb for Euro The euro lost 2.3 percent against the dollar, falling to 87.01 cents.
